Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this upside adjustment, driven by enduring global inflation pressures, tightens financing With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the specific case of the euro zone, total and core inflation have been declining for several quarters and, in december, they were below 1%.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the rest of the sub-baskets (regulated, tradables, and non-tradables) showed greater stability this month in comparison to what was seen in previous months.the decline in the annual change in the cpi for food – from 1.7% in january to 1.2% in february – again covered a inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as for the core inflation indicators, their average went from 2.4% in november to 2.5% in december.\n                "}]

could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in this context, the long-term interest rates in said countries have lowered and continue the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: retail sales reported by dane for the month of january fell to an annual rate of 4.5%, continuing the downward tendency begun in - 2008.\n                "}]

the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: international prices for food, raw materials and oil continue to decline.\n could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this largely reflects the effect of the global slowdown on colombia’s foreign trade as well as the drops seen in the production of petroleum and coal in the third quarter due to supply shocks which will provisionally be transitory.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence provides a neutral remark about the current economic situation, explaining the reasons for the slowdown, but does not express a clear stance on monetary policy."

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the available information suggests that in the year, domestic demand would have stalled versus 2015 as a result of the slowdown in consumption (households and government) and a fall in investment.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: they note that these adjustments bring the economy closer to a more sustainable future growth path and thus improve colombia's international financial conditions.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: (vii) the impact of the exchange rate on inflation and growth projections.\n With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mortgage lending rates remained stable at 12.9%.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the board of directors believes its expansive monetary policy contributes to economic growth in an environment characterized by a healthy financial system the board of directors agreed to make no change in the central bank’s intervention rate, which will remain at 3%.\n \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it is worth noting that, due to the basis of statistical comparison and to the normal agricultural cycle, the downward trend in annual food inflation could revert in the following months inflation expectations to december 2017 obtained from the monthly survey to financial analysts lowered, posting at 4.16%.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence mentions a downward trend in annual food inflation, which could lead to lower inflation expectations, providing room for a dovish monetary policy stance."

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: (viii) the difference between the benchmark rates in colombia and the united states has increased by 200 b since september 2007.\n                "}]

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in spite of that, the current values are relatively high compared to the historical average for the series.other indicators with information as of january available are: i) the total demand for electricity, which rose 2.9% annually, expanded at every level and its trend shows a positive slope; ii) petroleum production was one million fourteen thousand barrels daily on average which, although it shows a low growth of 0.3%, implies an increase compared to the last four months.thus, for all of 2014 the growth forecast remains within a range of 3.3% to 5.3% with 4.3% being the most probable figure financial variablesbank loans (n/ and f/c) registered an annual growth With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the group of foods presented smaller rhythms of increase, and upon excluding them from the cpi, their complement also slowed down in the latest month.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} &
